deck: The "galaxy far, far away" in which the Star Wars films and related works take place.
description:
Setting

The Star Wars Universe is set "long ago in a galaxy far far away." Though the Star Wars universe is set in a distant past, the level of technology present in the Star Wars Galaxy is far beyond anything in the current day. It features a large verity of different cultures and alien spices as well as intelligent machines known as droids. Space travel is very common and governments span across entire space systems. In addition to it's sci-fi components there is also a heavy mystical element in Star Wars know as "The Force" which connects all living things and grants certain gifted individuals a large variety of special powers. Stories in the universe range over the course of hundreds of years. Dates in the Universe are measures using the Galactic Standard Calendar.

Continuity

October 30, 2012, Disney bought out the rights to Star Wars and established an all new universe for Star Wars. All content that came out before Disney's acquisition of Star Wars are no longer considered part of the new continuity with the only exceptions being the movies (episodes 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, & 6) and the TV show Star Wars: The Clone Wars. All content to come out after Disney's acquisition is part of the new Star Wars universe. All off the previous continuity content is labeled as "Star Wars Legends."

Canon

This section is to objectively outline the main continuity of the Star Wars Universe.

Legends

This section is to objectively outline the continuity that has been discarded upon the rights being purchased by Disney.

  • Before the Republic (37,000 – 25,000 BBY)

  • Old Republic era (25,000 – 1000 BBY)

  • Rise of the Empire era (1000 – 0 BBY)

  • Rebellion era (0 – 5 ABY)

  • New Republic era (5 – 25 ABY)

  • New Jedi Order era (25 – 37 ABY)

  • Legacy era (37 ABY—)

deck: Marvel NOW!...the sequel?! This Marvel initiative makes it's return in October 2016 after the "Civil War II" storyline.
description:
Overview: Marvel NOW! (2016)

Originally launched in October 2012, the Marvel NOW! initiative began "the next chapter in the ongoing saga of the Marvel Universe". With a total of 4 "waves" (Wave One, Two, All-New Marvel NOW!, Avengers NOW!) Marvel NOW! officially ended in May 2015 at the start of the "Secret Wars" storyline.

The fallout of Secret Wars would setup the "All-New, All-Different Marvel" initiative in October 2015.

The return of Marvel NOW! was announced in May 2016 and begins in October of the same year. Following the conclusion of the "Civil War II" storyline, Marvel NOW! (2016), "refreshes and revitalizes" the Marvel Universe with new ongoing titles and teams.

NOTE!: New ongoing titles are marked with an asterisk (*).

deck: A line of Mature Readers titles published by DC, curated by Gerard Way and overseen by the Vertigo editorial staff.
description:
NOTE: This concept should only be attached to the first issues of the Young Animal line of titles.

Following DC's The New 52 initiative, the Vertigo imprint ceased publication of characters owned by DC Comics (with the exception of characters related to The Sandman) and almost exclusively published creator-owned content. Years later, following the Rebirth initiative, DC sought to once again publish stories featuring their characters which were more alternative in tone and appealed to a "Mature Readers" audience as they used to do through Vertigo, and launched the Young Animal line of comics through which to publish them.

The line was conceived and curated by rockstar and Eisner-winning comic writer Gerard Way. Taking inspiration from the kinds of stories Vertigo published in the 90s, Way conceived of 4 titles that would launch the line:

  • Doom Patrol - Written by Gerard Way, with art by Nick Derington
  • Shade, The Changing Girl - Written by Cecil Castellucci, with art by Marley Zarcone
  • Cave Carson Has a Cybernetic Eye - Written by Gerard Way and Jon Rivera, with art by Michael Avon Oeming
  • Mother Panic - Written by Jody Houser, with art by Tommy Lee Edwards

  • Bug!: The Adventures of Forager #1 (of 6) - Written by Lee Allred, with art by Mike Allred.

Most issues published under the Young Animal banner include a back-up story completely unrelated to the main content of the issue, usually written and drawn by creators who work in the underground comics scene doing their first work for a mainstream publisher.

Sometimes they`re used as weapons or death traps.

deck: Carnival is a Western Christian festive season that occurs before the liturgical season of Lent. The main events typically occur during February or early March, during the period historically known as Shrovetide (or Pre-Lent). Carnival typically involves a public celebration and/or parade combining some elements of a circus, masks, and a public street party. (Wikipedia)

deck: It was an in-house advertisement page based off the front page of the Daily Planet newspaper. It would highlight various stories that were issued for the month. Other features included Direct Currents, Ask the Answer Man, What is It Worth?, DC Profiles, trivia, word games and Hembeck.
description:
The Daily Planet was a weekly in house advertisement piece that appeared in DC Comics issues from 1976 (August 1976) to 1981 (March 1982). The advertisements were used as front page headlines on the Daily Planet newspaper. Several stories were featured as headlines with artwork taking the place of photos and a synopsis of the story with creator information. The Daily Planet initially appeared in all DC Comics issues up till August 1980. After that it only appeared in the DC Dollar Comics such as: (The Superman Family, World's Finest Comics, Detective Comics). Bob Rozakis was credited as the editor during the entire run. While, Anthony Tollin, Lynne Gelfer and Jodi Saviuk were credited as production during the run.

Direct Currents

It contained the issues that were being released that week with a very brief summary and creator data.

Ask the Answer Man

It was fan-based DC Comics related questions for Bob Rozakis the Answer Man.

What is It Worth?

It was fan-based DC Comics related questions for Bob Rozakis the Answer Man concerning the value of a particular comic book.

DC Profiles

Was a short biography of DC Comics creators and behind the scenes personnel at DC Comics. This feature also appeared as a part of the DC Feature Page.

Trivia

A trivia question was featured one week and the answer was featured in the following week's edition with a new trivia question.

Word Games

A crossword puzzle or word search game with DC Comics related answers within the clues.

Hembeck

A humor comic strip featuring various DC Comics characters by Fred Hembeck.
